1. Nf3 f6 2. Nc3 Nh6 3. g4 c6 4. d4 e6 5. Ng5 f5 6. e4 f4

6 ... f4

7. Nb5

We consider the responses 7 ... Bd6, Bb4+, Ba3 and (last) cxb5. (After 7 ... Qa5+, black's queen is in trouble and black also can't play Nxb4).

7 ... Bd6

8. Nc7+ Kf8 9. h4

9 ... Nxg4

10. e5

White threatens Bxf4.

10 ... f3 11. Rg1

11 ... g5

12. Bxg5

9 ... Na6

If black does not take on g4, white can take on h7.

10. Nxh7 Nb4 11. Qf3

7 ... Bb4+ 8. c3

7 ... Ba3 8. bxa3

7 ... cxb5 8. Bb5 Nc6

9. Rg1

9 ... Nxg4

10. Qh5+ g6 11. Qd5

11 ... d6

12. Qxd6+ Ke7

13. Bd7 e5

14. Bxc8

We'll consider 14 ... g5, Rd8 and Ke8. Playing g5 immediately has to be considered since it pressures the kingside and allows Kf7. Rd8 and Ke8 also will be considered since they immediately put pressure on the queenside (for example, after Ke8, white cannot play d5 because black has Bc5).

14 ... g5

14 ... Rd8

15. Bd2

15 ... exd4 16. Bb4+

16 ... Ke6 17. Bd6

15 ... a5 16. d5

15 ... Ke8 16. Bb4

16 ... Bc5

17. Rd1

14 ... Ke8

15. b4
